turnover.translation[0].definitions[0].d: the amount of business done during a particular period
turnover.translation[0].definitions[0].e: The illicit drugs industry has an annual turnover of some £200 billion.
turnover.translation[0].definitions[1].d: the rate at which a particular kind of goods is sold
turnover.translation[0].definitions[2].d: the rate at which people leave an organization and are replaced by others
turnover.translation[0].definitions[2].e: a high degree of labour turnover among women
Low pay accounts for the high turnover.
turnover.translation[1].definitions[0].d: the amount of business done in a particular period of time, measured by the amount of money obtained from customers for goods or services that have been sold
turnover.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The commercial services business unit had an annual turnover of 3.9 billion kronor.
turnover.translation[1].definitions[1].d: the rate at which workers leave an organization and are replaced by others
turnover.translation[1].definitions[1].e: Morale among child-care workers is low, and turnover is more than 40% a year.
Contract workers have a high turnover rate.
turnover.translation[1].definitions[2].d: the rate at which goods are sold
turnover.translation[1].definitions[2].e: Our business success is built on a fast turnover of merchandise.
turnover.translation[1].definitions[3].d: the number of shares traded on a stockmarket during a particular period of time, usually a day, or the number of shares traded in a particular company
turnover.translation[1].definitions[3].e: Stocks closed 16 per cent lower at 27360 points amid light turnover (=not much trading).
The company’s shares gained 20p to 463p on turnover of 1.1 million shares.
